content.description:
This is the 2nd route left of the Pistol Bully/Clam cave, and it's a good one.

Climbing to the first bolt involves some choss navigation skills, but once you've climbed under the 2nd bolt you're in for some great vertical pocket pulling.
content.location: 2nd route left the Clam cave. Look for choss at the start then an awesome vertical golden shield from bolt 2 to the chains.

content.description: Bouldery start leads to good pockets to get a quick shake. Choose the line through the crux that suits your style then gain the block to the right. Continue right of the bolt line to pockets then follow them to the chains. The crux is down low but the pump will most likely be the biggest obstacle to success.
content.protection: Bolts to anchors with chains and biners
content.location: On 2nd tier from the bottom (left) in upper cave. Left of Beam and Coke.

content.description:
Another excellent line tackling the second cave uphill from the main trail.  Start below the obvious flake on the right side of the cave on crimpers, then traverse the juggy flake.  Clip the third bolt, then commit to a series of mail slots and thrilling two-finger pockets to jugs at the top of the cave.

Joins Beam and Coke (5.12d) at the third bolt.  For me, the crux was just getting to the chains;  it's thin above the last bolt.

Decently adhered choss starts the route which climbs through a limestoney/conglomerate section. Once you pull over the bulge above that zone you're in for some quality stone movement.

The crux on this climb isn't like Feature A' so read it right the first time.
content.location: First route left of Feature Attraction.

content.description:
This route sports the best rock from bottom to top of any route at the crag.

The first 2 bolts are the physical crux so try to get a good rest right after. Fantastic pockets and jugs the entire way.
content.location: Low cave on the uphill side of it to the right of the clam (deep in the cave), and left of 4 Deep which sports heinous monos. Starts with a two finger pocket for the left, and crimp for the right.

content.description:
Right in front of the grove of trees uphill from Slice of Pie and the second deep cave of the crag.  Climbs out steep pockets via big moves to a large rail three bolts up.  The rest of the route traverses up and right on adequate holds.

This is pretty soft compared to the other .12s on the wall, and thus probably a good choice for breaking into the grade.  Getting off-route at all after the fourth bolt will lead you to a garden of choss.
content.protection: 7 bolts.  6 had fixed draws when we did it.  Stick clipping the first bolt is a good idea since the first moves are the hardest.

content.description: Although short, not a bad warm up.   The crux is thin and warms up the fingers nicely.   Worth doing, rock quality is pretty decent.  Has cleaned up well.
content.protection: 5 bolts, 1 fixed chain draw, Chain anchors
content.location: Between Vagrant Circle, 11d and Half Cab,12b

content.description: A short climb that packs a punch before the chains.   Climb up to the large flake and traverse a bit left and then head straight up from the end of the flake.   Clip the next bolt from a good pocket above the flake (long draw helps) and then figure out the crux to get to the jug below the chains.   Good rock quality.  Harder than Slice of Pie for sure, although shorter.
content.location: This route shares the start with Slice of Pie.   Located near the upper portion of the cliffline.

content.description: Easy edges and pockets up a slightly under vertical face bring you to a rightward traverse on mondo buckets (can be sharp). Rock up over the bulge, and contemplate the upper crux. This vertical face sports the technical and redpoint crux.
content.location: This is the first route left out of the large Clam cave. Also the first route right of little buddy.

content.description: Starts with a move left off a tweaky 1-2 finger pocket to jugs. Progress up using sinker pockets and some dynamic movement. Trend right to chain draw. Execute the red point crux moves then paddle up sinker pockets to the head wall. Good stone.
content.protection: Bolts to anchors with chains and biners
content.location: On lowest tier of upper cave. Left and below Tenacious Z.

content.description: Start with a mono that makes you feel like a hero, but the mono adventure doesn't stop there. Fight through the first 4 bolts, which features two monos(including the starting hold). After that make long pulls in between good pockets(and very few feet) until you reach the last mono of the route. Then enjoy the jug haul to a reachy anchor clip. Some of the best stone in the area all the way, awesome pockets, cool movement. Whats not to love! This route would be a 4 star route if it was transported to American Fork for sure. If you finish and think, "that was too easy," then try linking the Clam to Hoopti(13.a?), a pumpfest for sure.
content.protection: Most of the time there are draws perma-draws, however, they take them down at the end of the season every year. There are 7 bolts not including the chains (I believe).
content.location: Route just the the right of Piston Bully. This is the last route to the right in the first cave you come to from the trail. There is an obvious deep mono start hold.

content.description:
A vertical to slightly overhanging route third from the bottom of the wall.  Climb slabby stone to two bolts then up a vertical flake system to a small ledge.  Have a rest, clip the last bolt and fire the roof to clip the chains.

Quite good for the wall, and a good warm-up for the steeper routes uphill.

Some funky climbing gets you through bolt 2 to a big horn jug, then mostly pockets through the roof(crux) and eases up as the angle decreases. Super good. Falling at bolt 1-2 may result in a swinger into the ground. Book gives it a 12c, but states pulling the roof is 12d. We'll call it 12c/d
content.location: The steepest route in the lower cave, starting in the back. In between Half Cab and Piston Bully. One of the poorest belay stances at the crag.

content.description: Climb fun pockets up through 2 bolts to a chossy section with a bunch of loose edges and bolt 3. Traverse directly right using good ledges for feet and bust out the last 2 bolts using deep pocks.
content.protection: 5 bolts to chains. Book shows 4 bolts but I clipped 5.
content.location: The book lists this as route 4. Just down from the better looking "vagrant circle" which starts on the lowest stepped platform.  Look for right trending bolt line with crappy belay stance on a slopey rock.

content.description: This climb has pretty exceptional movement on some steep terrain.  The rock on this one is solid.   Sinker pockets to the 3rd bolt.  From 3rd to 4th bolt is the crux with some powerful moves to reach a good jug rail.  From here, it joins Slice of Pie for all of the hard bits on that route.
content.location: Start on the terrace just below the start to Slice of Pie.
